18.59.text:
As a performance artist
I've always been interested

22.20.text:
in the notion of
the body as a kind

25.12.text:
of evolutionary architecture
that gradually becomes aware

32.03.text:
and operates effectively
in the world.

34.82.text:
And this idea also is
premised on the fact

40.48.text:
that the body is not
particularly well designed.

45.70.text:
I mean there's some
obvious examples,

49.22.text:
This body has to take in gulps
of air constantly to survive.

58.05.text:
If it loses 10 percent of
its body fluids it's dead.

62.74.text:
If its internal temperature
varies three

64.92.text:
or four degrees it's
in serious health risk.

71.30.text:
We live to an average of
75 years in good health

75.48.text:
and then we gradually
deteriorate and die.

78.99.text:
Now, this is a problem
if you're already 68.

85.22.text:
[laughter] It's also a time of
what I call circulating flesh.

92.51.text:
in my body today
may be circulating

95.42.text:
in your body tomorrow if
you happen to be O positive.

99.82.text:
We can extract organs
from one body

103.27.text:
and insert them into
another body.

107.20.text: At a medical conference in Paris

109.74.text:
about 12 years ago I met the
first double hand transplant.

115.01.text:
We can actually stitch the hands
of a cadaver onto the limbs

121.65.text:
of another person
and reanimate them.

124.61.text:
After six months this person had
a rudimentary sense of touch,

133.64.text:
and he could animate
the cadaver fingers.

137.88.text:
So, it's very disconcerting if
you have a kidney transplant,

145.22.text:
If I have to shake the hands
of a person whose hands came

151.56.text:
from the body of someone
previously deceased then it

157.38.text: might be a bit more problematic.

159.72.text:
So, it's a time of
circulating flesh.
